description: From Middle English blemisshen, blemissen, from Old French blemiss-, stem of Old French blemir, blesmir (“make pale, injure, wound, bruise”) (French blêmir), from Old Frankish *blesmjan, *blasmijan (“to make pale”), from Old Frankish *blasmi (“pale”), from Proto-Germanic *blasaz (“white, pale”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰel- (“to shine”). Cognate with Dutch bles (“white spot”), German blass (“pale”), Old English āblered (“bare, uncovered, bald, shaven”).

entries.meaning: A small flaw which spoils the appearance of something, a stain, a spot.
examples: Ye shall offer at your own will a male without blemish, of the beeves, of the sheep, or of the goats.

entries.meaning: A moral defect; a character flaw.

verbs.description: blemish (third-person singular simple present blemishes, present participle blemishing, simple past and past participle blemished)

examples: Generally, varieties in current use for processing are resilient, if not wholly resistant to blemishing diseases and disorders.

entries.meaning: To tarnish (reputation, character, etc.); to defame.
examples: There had nothing passed betwixt us that might blemish reputation.
